Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Mitchell,

I have not spoken much in this group.  I am a lurker and intend =
on using NEAT in the future.  For now, I am using simple feedforward networ=
ks making an evaluation of a board state with a ply management system.  I a=
m replicating the experiments in the book Blondie24 by David Fogel.  I have=
 developed a framework for playing "generic" perfect information non-random=
 two player games.  My first implementation is obviously checkers.  My goal=
 implemetation is Go.

My gut feel on your assertion is that I agree.  I se=
nse that min/max (or some specialization of it like Alpha/Beta) will likely=
 be present in more complex game playing ANNs.  It seems it would take an e=
normous amount of searching in a game space for a GA to have an ANN of any =
type converge to the min/max mechanism regardless of the ANN meta-architect=
ure approach.  In fact, it seems more likely for an ANN using GA to attempt=
 to use the pattern recognition approach many times before stumbling on a r=
udimentary version of min/max (it would require recurrent connections in th=
e ANN and in unique combinations).

However, I do think that it is possible=
 for ANNs to suggest moves at which to take a deeper look.  For example, in=
 the domain of Go, there are way too many possible moves for even a full pl=
y search of depth 2 to yield any level of effectiveness.  The breadth of av=
ailable "legal" moves in Go starts at 361 and stays above 100 for almost th=
e entire game.  Worse, thanks to captures and Ko, the number of legal moves=
 is not guaranteed to descend.

As such, some sort of mechanism to priortiz=
e looking at some subset of "legal" moves is essential (if you are familiar=
 with Go, you could refer to the patterns described in "Go Proverbs").  I s=
uspect an ANN that specializes in small regional patterns will likely be ab=
le to be evolved that reduces the "legal" move set substantially.  Even the=
n, it would need to reduce it to less than 3% FOR EACH PLY DEPTH to make a =
ply search depth of 6 or 8 even reasonable computationally.  That is one he=
ll of an efficiency, +97% *accurate* reduction in legal moves.

At the pres=
ent time, I am sort of seeing an ANN sandwich; ANN #1 takes a set of all le=
gal moves and prioritizes them.  A ply manager then recursively calls ANN #=
1 until it reaches a certain depth.  Then the ply manager presents the resu=
ltant board state to ANN #2 for a full board evaluation.  This cycle contin=
ues until a move is deemed most effective and then utilized.

The way in wh=
ich ANN #1 evolves (mutation and/or feedback on a fixed topology, direct en=
coding using NEAT, indirect encoding using many different types of topologi=
cal techniques including NEAT) can be completely different from the way in =
which ANN #2 evolves.  This produces a meta-GA GA approach; a GA for discov=
ering the ideal GA techinique for each of the two ANNs.  As you can imagine=
, we now have a HUGE computational space.  And this assumes two ANNs and so=
me form of the min-max algorithm.  And there are other "techniques" for cap=
turing static patterns in a pattern matching DB that might be more efficien=
t in the long run.

Anyway, using Go as the goal and realizing the amount o=
f computational power required to advance on the Go goal with GA techniques=
 has me thinking of all sorts of ways to develop "static" structures as qui=
ckly as possible to minimize the amount of things the ANNs must evolve to s=
tructure and (re)solve.  Hence, my general agreement .  :^)


Jim O'Flahert=
y


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Mitchell Timin 
  To: neat@yaho=
ogroups.com 
  Sent: Saturday, December 13, 2003 8:45 PM
  Subject: [neat] =
board games


  I've been playing connect 4 here:
  http://www.checkers.ws/=
board_games/connect_four_games/connect_four/connect_four.htm

  I had not k=
nown this game before.  This program beats
  me almost every time. :)

  To=
 those who want to make ANNs that play board games,
  I think the use of mi=
ni-max is required for any game
  more complex than tic-tac-toe.  This is m=
y somewhat
  educated opinion, but I don't think its possible to
  play the=
 typical board game just from pattern
  recognition.  I have two arguments:=
 1) is that humans
  cannot do it; they must look ahead in order to play
  =
decently, and 2) no one has succeeded with an ANN that
  doesn't look ahead=
.  Even with tic-tac-toe, I don't
  thing there has been and ANN produced t=
hat plays a
  perfect game.

  People have used ANNs very successfully to e=
valuate
  the board after looking ahead a few ply.

  =3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
  Mit=
chell Timin
  http://annevolve.sourceforge.net

  _________________________=
_________

anion.yahoo.com/
